title: Monday, 6th February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

Thought we might kick off with an advert

PM11:01am

A Budweiser advert

11:01 am
PM11:01am

From the Superbowl, which I didn't watch

PM11:01am
PM11:01am

It's 'controversial' cos it features a migrant

11:02 am
PM11:02am

It reminded me of something tho.

PM11:02am

I don't often buy beer -- at least not from supermarkets

PM11:02am

But went to get some Czech Bud last week -- adn there wasn't any

11:02 am
PM11:03am

But there was lots and lots and lots of American Budweiser

PM11:03am

When did this happen?

PM11:03am

Do people in Britain now drink this American version???

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Or is it just the ABI monopoly in action?

PM11:04am

Sainsbury and Co-op -- all the larger with ABI

PM11:04am

Sure there was a separate shelf with lots of craft beers etc. But the mainstream lager was all ABI stuff

11:04 am
PM11:04am

And no Czech Bud

PM11:04am

Yes, i mean Budvar

PM11:05am

I'm no expert on this

11:05 am
PM11:05am

But looked monopolistic to me

PM11:05am

Anyway, he's an even better Superbowl ad

PM11:05am
11:05 am
BE11:06am

Hm. I'm not an expert here either .......

BE11:06am

............ But isn't the Budweiser-Budvar thing the longest-running copyright dispute, like, ever?

BE11:06am

As in, more than a hundred years?

11:06 am
PM11:07am

I thought they came to some agreement

BE11:07am

I thought so too. But if supermarkets here aren't stocking Budvar (I'm calling it that for convenience) all of a sudden, that's interesting.

BE11:08am

Anyway, that's the kind of thing we could look at if we weren't paid to look at stocks, so let's look at stocks.

11:08 am
undefined
PM11:08am

Guess so

PM11:08am

So this big rally on Wall St on Friday

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Not much follow through that I can asee

PM11:08am

see

PM11:09am

Yeah, Footsie up 20 points.

11:08 am
PM11:09am

But the Dow was up a full 1 %

PM11:09am

Maybe this tearing up all the financial regulations idea doesn't cross the pond

BE11:10am

Yeah, we're a bit directionless this morning. One could argue we had the Dodd-Frank bump on Friday ......

11:10 am
BE11:10am

.... With Barclays and Pru leading.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 231.50, up 2.65 (+1.16%), High: 233.35, Low: 229.20, Volume: 11.99m
Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,600, down 1 (-0.06%), High: 1,604, Low: 1,594, Volume: 1.21m
11:10 am
PM11:11am

Said I was speechless here on Friday when that Cohn stuff first appeared in the Journal

PM11:11am

But I still am baffled

PM11:11am

So we had a financial crisis -- which brought us QE

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Which led to this huge growth of inequality -- adn then populism and rage

PM11:11am

That brought us Trump

PM11:12am

So the first thing he does -- one of the first things

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Is he tries to get rid of the regulations and controls that were supposed to stop another financial crisis

PM11:12am

World turned upside down

PM11:13am

Keep the rage going -- taht must be the plan

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Yeah, well ..............

BE11:14am

Amazing quote here

BE11:14am

11:14 am
BE11:14am

That's the CEO of Bank of America

PM11:14am

It is

BE11:14am

Pretending that he doesn't understand how banking works.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

It's from here: https://www.wsj.co...ulation-1486158695

BE11:15am

Anyway, let's turn this back to the UK.

PM11:15am

sure

11:15 am
undefined
BE11:15am

HSBC positive on banks ......

BE11:15am

Same theme. They have too much capital.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Far too much. Loaded up with CET1 so they need to give it back to shareholders.

BE11:17am

Because rates have expanded the NIM and that won't ever contract, ever ever again.

BE11:17am

Lloyds goes up to buy.

11:17 am
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 66.61, up 0.756 (+1.15%), High: 66.70, Low: 66.15, Volume: 37.23m
BE11:17am

Here's page one.

BE11:17am

Return to go: in the week following the UK’s EU Membership Referendum, the combined market capitalisation of Barclays, Lloyds and RBS collapsed from GBP112bn to a low point of GBP74bn, but by year end it was almost back to the starting point.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The market has been right to re-think its initial negative view on Brexit. Long-term rates are back to their pre-referendum levels helping to maintain hedge income and there has been no evidence of credit quality deterioration. On one hand this suggests the UK may have successfully navigated the storm. But on the other, it may be that the calm before the storm has persisted longer than anticipated. Which-ever view ultimately proves correct, the consequences of Brexit for UK banks now look very different from what they did last summer.

BE11:17am

UK regulators see the sector as adequately capitalised. In consequence, organically generated equity, which would otherwise have been utilised for building CET1, becomes available for dividends. Lloyds has already reached this point; the combination of a high level of revenues and profit per RWA combined with limited lending/RWA growth implies underlying dividend capacity is well in excess of the 3p the group is likely to pay for 2016. In light of this factor, we update valuations and upgrade Lloyds to Buy from Hold.

BE11:18am

For Barclays, the sale and disposal of Non-Core activities is strongly value accretive and the improved outlook for fixed income markets could be an important catalyst. The profitability of RBS continues to lag peers. The highly uncertain outcome of US litigation and fines remains the main focus of interest.

11:17 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 231.20, up 2.35 (+1.03%), High: 233.35, Low: 229.20, Volume: 12.12m
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 227.80, down 0.7 (-0.31%), High: 229.60, Low: 226.00, Volume: 4.97m
undefined
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Before moving on from the theme ......

BE11:19am

....... the retreating fiduciary rule thingmy had a positive effect for Pru on Friday, as we noted.

PM11:19am

This is also crazy de-regulation, to my mind

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Fine if you want to finesse this stuff -- but to just strike it out. Asking for chaos -- and greedy opportunism

BE11:20am

Hm. From a shareholder perspective, Pru has a big US variable-annuities business and it'll be useful not to have any responsibility for selling people things they want.

BE11:21am

What might've been missed, however, was another round of Chinese capital controls.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

I'll let RBC pick up the theme.

PM11:21am

oooh

BE11:21am

The Chinese regulator has introduced another rule to stem the
outflow of monies to Hong Kong, and in contrast to previous regulations we expect this one to reduce offshore sales. Prudential has been the most successful insurer at attracting monies from mainland China and therefore is particularly at risk, at a time when its other large Asian geographies are showing slower sales growth.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

So this is the limit on buying life insurance or investment-related insurance products with foreign currency thing.

BE11:23am

Prudential has confirmed that the significant majority of its sales are lower than the US$50,000 limit so this regulation will catch many customers for the very first time, in our view. The quick succession of regulations also suggests to us that further restrictions will be implemented if capital flight continues.

PM11:23am

Chinese authorities desperate to stop the money escaping

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Analysing local regulatory returns we note that Prudential’s offshore sales declined by 12% in Q3 vs. Q2 - it was the only insurer in the top 5 to see lower sales. In contrast onshore sales grew by 15%.

BE11:24am

Due to the new restriction, we reduce our sales forecast for Hong Kong by 7% (2017E) and 24% (2018E). Prudential’s Asian sales have become increasingly reliant on Hong Kong, which ccounted for 56% of sales in Asia in 2016H1. Our forecast CAGR for worldwide sales falls from 7% to 4%.

PM11:24am

Maybe they should start at home -- on the credit growth front

11:24 am
PM11:24am

(Sorry, will stop interrupting)

BE11:25am

Not a huge hit to Pru earnings, and one that might be in the market already. But it's an odd circumstance where Pru is making cash on regulatory rollback in its most mature market and getting it in the neck in its biggest developing market.

BE11:25am

That's not how it's supposed to work.

11:25 am
undefined
PM11:25am

Too right

PM11:25am

World turned upside down

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Hey look at this

PM11:25am

Frontier Developments plc (AIM: FDEV; "Frontier" or the "Group"), a leading independent creator of video games, is pleased to announce that it has licenced rights from a major Hollywood studio to develop its third game franchise based on an enduring movie franchise of global renown.

PM11:25am

What could that be?

11:25 am
PM11:26am

enduring movie franchise of global renown?

PM11:26am

Do speculate on this over on the right

PM11:26am

This is the Elite Dangerous folk, who have come along to Camp AV last couple of years --

11:26 am
PM11:26am

David Braben and co

PM11:27am

I don't know which enduring movie franchises of global renown are already video games

PM11:27am

So can't offer a view

11:27 am
PM11:27am

All good suggestions on the right so far

Frontier Developments PLC (FDEV:LSE): Last: 286.30, up 8.8 (+3.17%), Volume: 9.16k
PM11:28am

Market in that always seems so quiet

11:28 am
undefined
PM11:29am

(Miguel -- Tomb Raider was a game to start with)

BE11:29am

So, what else do we have? Not much in the way of news.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

There's a good note from Shore out on AstraZeneca, though shares are going the wrong way.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,393, up 34.5 (+0.79%), High: 4,409, Low: 4,352, Volume: 734.12k
PM11:30am

Saw the snap on that -- but not the full note

11:30 am
BE11:31am

It's well worth reading, even if the shares aren't behaving.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:31am

As in, the Mystic trial. Due soon. Binary event. You remember.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

According to Shore, AZN management look to be setting us up to consider Overall Survival ratio as the important readout.

BE11:32am

Rather than Progression Free Survival, the pending reading, which Shore reckons has been quietly de-emphasised.

BE11:32am

And you've got AstraZeneca bundling in monotherapy as the endpoint. It gets a bit noodly from here ....

11:32 am
BE11:33am

... but I think the argument is that, in the wake of the Opdivo failure, ASN suspects the combo durva + treme might only be useful for patients who've failed monotherapy.

BE11:33am

Therefore, the mid-point Mystic reading -- due shortly, remember -- will either be bad or defying of any useful interpretation.

BE11:34am

And we probably have to wait for 2018 for the overall survival stuff.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

I'll stop demonstrating my limited understanding and just quote a bit.

BE11:34am

We note an increasing emphasis on the value of the OS endpoint in evaluating IO therapies in Astra’s communications with investors. This leaves us more cautious on whether we will see a significant, clinically-meaningful effect on the PFS metric at mid-17F, with a high clinical bar in “high-PD-L1 expressing” (more than 50%) patients set by Merck’s (MRK, NR, CNP) Keytruda monotherapy (PFS 10.3mos vs chemo 6mos). Astra’s OS data is not expected until 2018F and it remains to be seen whether the market is willing to be patient in the ensuing period.

BE11:35am

Actually, that's quite far down the note. Let me spin back to the summary.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Following Astra’s full year 2016 update (2 Feb), we are increasingly cautious ahead of the MYSTIC trial in 1L NSCLC and see little reason to own the shares post the ex-dividend date (16 Feb) and ahead of this binary catalyst (mid-17F). We acknowledge that the risk/reward on the data has become marginally skewed to the upside (15-20% up/10-15% down), but management’s comments around their confidence in the Overall Survival (OS) endpoint (expected in 2018F) relative to the Progression Free Survival (PFS) metric, together with recent disclosures (Jan-17) around inclusion of monotherapy OS as a primary endpoint, further increase our caution around disappointing data (i.e. in the context of the relative clinical benefit of the combo vs mono and the commercial opportunity) at mid-17F. We also note the change in language to “PD-L1 expressing tumours” (versus “high” and “low” previously), which could suggest decreased confidence in the use of the durva/treme combo in PD-L1 negative patients, the more significant commercial opportunity.

BE11:35am

And one more par ............

BE11:35am

It remains possible for Astra to carve out some form of 'file-able' data from MYSTIC at mid-17F, given the (statistical) flexibility retained by the company. In the event of such 'positive' data we would need to consider the totality of the data before taking a view on the ultimate commercial market opportunity. For example more recent commentary from the company has suggested that in high PD-L1 expressors monotherapy may be the better option. If durva mono were to demonstrate significant effect in 1L NSCLC PD-L1-expressing patients at any cutoff below Merck’s 50% this would represent a niche for Astra as the second PD-1/PD-L1 in the 1L NSCLC setting. However, this would be smaller than the commercial opportunity for the combo in low expressors, and further we see the monotherapy opportunity as highly competitive with Merck having a significant lead.

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Yes, this is noodly

BE11:36am

The rest of the argument is that, while AstraZeneca has lots of potentially good stuff in the pipeline, you're probably best to wait until after durva + treme fails.

BE11:36am

Which it might not! But it probably will.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Okay, that's me had my daily fix. We can move off drugs now.

undefined
PM11:38am

I see Malcolm Barr has a big shout out for our Alex Barker

11:38 am
PM11:38am

(Brussels)

PM11:38am

On the Brexit bill

PM11:38am

Alex Barker, the Brussels bureau chief of the Financial Times, and the Centre for European Reform have provided a valuable service with an excellent piece explaining the debate around “The €60 billion Brexit bill”. The full piece, which is 14 pages long and written in an accessible manner, can be read at the link below.

To summarize: the largest single contributor to estimates of the UK’s liability comes from spending commitments which the EU has entered into over time (mainly spending under “Cohesion” programs) but where payments have not yet been made. The UK’s share for unfunded pension liabilities of those who have worked for the EU is the next largest. Based on exactly how one appraises the extent of the UK’s liability for commitments, and how one assesses the UK’s share, the piece generates a range of liabilities for the UK of between €24.5bn and €73bn.

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Barker provides a lucid commentary about how debate over this liability may negatively influence the early stages of Brexit negotiations. He suggests that an eventual compromise could plausibly see the UK pay around €17bn on exit (roughly equal to the UK’s net contribution over 2019/20), with an arbitration panel or international court asked to determine the extent of any other liability, while also committing to paying an annual sum to cover participation in various specific projects (perhaps with some payments for pensions liabilities disguised within it). The key point to recognize, however, is that getting to anywhere close to this from the current position of both sides will be a difficult journey.

PM11:39am

I should note that this "valuable service" is a public service

PM11:39am

As in...

11:38 am
PM11:39am

http://cer.org.uk/...policy-brief/2017/€60-billion-brexit-bill-how-disentangle-britain-eu-budget

PM11:39am

At the Centre for European Reform

PM11:39am

You can download his paper there

11:39 am
undefined
BE11:40am

Right, what else then?

PM11:40am

Just Eat -- any movement there?

11:40 am
Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 546.00, down 6 (-1.09%), High: 552.50, Low: 545.00, Volume: 208.53k
PM11:40am

UBS reiterating their sell recommendation

PM11:41am

But they've done one of these Evidence Labs things

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Clocking the app download numbers

PM11:41am

Across the sector

PM11:41am

Aggregators now 75% of takeaway delivery app downloads, from

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Hang on

PM11:42am

Restaurant delivery aggregator apps now account for three quarters of all takeaway delivery app downloads in the Apple app store, up from under half in 2014. Share has largely been won from pizza delivery restaurants. Three-sided logistics players – such as Deliveroo and UberEATS – have been the biggest drivers of these share gains, rising from 1% of the total in 2014 to 23% in 2016, and 26% in the year-to-date. Two-sided marketplace players – such as Just Eat and hungryhouse – enjoyed a spike in 2015, but have since lost share, and now represent just under half of the market.

PM11:42am

Just Eat has been the most downloaded takeaway delivery app in the Apple app store since overtaking Domino's Pizza in March 2015. It now represents one in three of all takeaway delivery app downloads. But it is no longer winning market share. The app peaked at 39% of app downloads in June 2015, but fell to a low of 29% in August 2016, before recovering to 32% in December 2016. hungryhouse fared worse, dropping from a 24% share in September 2015 to 12% in December 2016. Deliveroo and UberEATS represent 15% and 8% of app downloads respectively, having launched in July 2015 and June 2016 respectively.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Just Eat's current share of the online-ordered UK takeaway market is c57%, we estimate, and c28% of the total market (including telephone). Our app analysis makes us comfortable with our estimate of its reaching 36% of the total market by 2020E, but we struggle to price in more than this (Just Eat targets 45% in the long term). Our valuation is based on a discounted cash flow model.

PM11:43am

I will try and usual place that later

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Hm. Could revisit Reckitt, I guess .......

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,026, down 103 (-1.44%), High: 7,111, Low: 7,014, Volume: 455.08k
BE11:44am

Suggestions around the weekend press that we're getting this Mead deal sooner rather than later. As in, this week or early next.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Lots of cynicism about the logic too, and questions why Reckitt suddenly feels the need to bulk up with a target that's outside its normal USP.

BE11:45am

RBC put these concerns into note form, thusly.

BE11:46am

In 2013 CEO Rakesh Kapoor set out three criteria required from an acquisition: it should be strategically compelling, be worth more to RB than its existing owner and create value, not just increase EPS. We’re not sure Mead Johnson ticks any of these boxes. Underperform.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

We’ve heard two schools of thought regarding RB’s putative acquisition of Mead Johnson: it’s cleverly opportunistic, with the most likely counter-bidder (Danone) fully occupied acquiring WhiteWave and the Mead Johnson share price down 25% since the summer; or it’s a sign that RB is running out of steam and management is buying growth to compensate. We’re not sure the two are mutually exclusive.

BE11:47am

(...... The idea of Nestle as an alternative counterbidder just doesn't fly, incidentally. Antitrust. So you're looking at someone leftfield.)

BE11:47am

Strategically, Mead Johnson’s infant milk formula (IMF) business can be described as adjacent to RB’s existing business, but some way from being strategically compelling in our view. RB’s management has no experience of the IMF business, so it feels like guesswork whether the business will be worth more as part of RB than a stand-alone entity. What we do know is that RB has never tried anything remotely on this scale: if it goes through, the purchase of Mead Johnson will cost almost twice as much as all the other acquisitions RB has ever made put together.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

We think the risk associated with the RB investment case has increased materially, while the prospect of a slowing core business and steeply declining ROIC is not one we regard with equanimity. We introduce a 5% ‘reinvestment risk’ discount in calculating our Target Price as we already do for Danone. Together with a reduction to our margin forecast, this generates an Adjusted Present Value derived Target Price of £63 (-10%). Consequently we reduce our recommendation to Underperform.

BE11:48am

We've also got Barclays mounting a defence of the deal.

BE11:48am

I quote: "Condoms to baby food - not as absurd as it might seem"

11:49 am
BE11:49am

............ which is nearly as bad as last week's Bloomberg headline ....

BE11:49am

Adding Baby Food to Condoms Helps Reckitt Boss Forget Lousy Year

BE11:49am

That's a mental image for you.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

https://www.bloomb...-forget-lousy-year

BE11:50am

Anyway .......... Here's Barclays.

BE11:50am

A scarcity of available consumer health assets may have forced Reckitt’s hand to explore an acquisition of Mead Johnson. However, what may seem an opportunistic left field move, and not without risks, offers strategic as well as the more obvious financial attractions. Infant nutrition is an attractive consumer category with good emerging market growth prospects and returns. Reckitt can accelerate the geographic roll out of Mead, in particular leveraging consumer health distribution synergies. Mead would also enhance RB’s EM presence, including exposure to China. Reckitt’s relative rating to staples is now a more palatable 5% P/E premium (pre any deal accretion). However, uncertainty around the terms of any transaction and poor trading momentum (at both RB and Mead), means we remain EW on RB. We have adjusted our earnings estimates to reflect recent currency movements.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

What’s the rationale? Mead would contribute 24% of pro forma sales and lift exposure to Health from 34% to 50%. Sales from EMs would increase to 43% (from 35%) with China increasing from 2-3% to c.9%. Benchmark consumer health this is not. However, Infant nutrition has amongst the most favorable growth prospects within the staples universe, and should be accretive to RB’s category growth rate. Reckitt’s scale and geographic presence allows for white space expansion, notably where RB has a strong health distribution presence (Russia, India, Europe).

The numbers; A cash transaction at $90 per share (as per both company releases), would value Mead on 18.8x EBITDA (EV $18.4bn). By no means cheap, but should be seen in the context for Danone-Numico (21.7x) and Nestle-Wyeth (19.8x). Assuming a range of cost savings of £240m to £360m and cost of debt of 3.0% to 3.5% would see potential Year 3 EPS accretion of 15% to 19%, with 2017E net debt EBITDA at 3.8x. Year 3 ROIC of 5.5% to 5.9%, is underwhelming, but no more so than recent staples transactions.

A done deal? The probability of third party interest seems low in our view. Nestle faces too many antitrust hurdles Meanwhile, Danone on completion of its pending WhiteWave acquisition will have net debt to EBITDA of 3.4x (2017E). As an entirely new category to Reckitt, this transaction potentially faces minimal regulatory hurdles.

BE11:51am

There. That's that.

undefined
11:51 am
PM11:51am

Very comprehensive. Thank you

PM11:51am

Ryanair miss

PM11:52am

Stock off a couple of %

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Minor miss. No change to guidance.

PM11:52am

But it's still v confident statement

PM11:52am

http://www.investe...1702060700070463W/

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Revenue €1,345m vs consensus of €1,361m

PM11:52am

So a near miss

BE11:52am

Profit €95m versus consensus of €99m

11:52 am
PM11:52am

(Sorry)

BE11:52am

(Hm.)

BE11:53am

It's pressure on fares, rather than the load factor (which is at a record 95%, which is pretty incredible).

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Average fare down 17% to.................. €33!

PM11:54am

incredible

BE11:55am

It's an amazing business that seems to capture a demand for people to fly somewhere, anywhere, providing it's cheap enough.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

One can extrapolate that into a quite dark statement about the human character and its propensity for restless misery, but instead here's Goodbody.

BE11:56am

Pretax came in at €94.7m vs our and consensus forecast for €99m (consensus range €74m to 127m). Q3 yields came in down 17% yoy vs prior guidance of down 13-15% but Q4 yields are guided as ‘to decline by as much as -15%’, which can be read as a positive vs the Q3 outrun and stays in line with the top end of prior guidance.
Current FY17 PAT guidance kept at €1.30-1.35bn so this is a positive. At the mid-point of €1,325m, this would suggest clean PAT of €63m in Q4 vs last year’s €51m so good recovery despite there being no Easter this year (estimated lost ~$20m).
In terms of Q3 revenues of €1,345m, these were €6m lower than our forecasts, with fares down 16.6% yoy vs our 16% forecast, however, Q3 ex-fuel cost -6% yoy vs our -5.1%, with airport charges of note as volume deals keep delivering. Guidance on FY17 ex-fuel cost now stands at -4% yoy, which is better than prior guidance of -3% (€/£ FX helping) and in line with our modelled -4.2%. However, with Q4 guidance better than our current -16% assumption, moving this to -15% adds €7m to our PAT forecast and moves us to €1.303bn,
although this is still at the bottom of the maintained guidance.
Overall, the Q317 release should be taken well by the market. However, focus is going to be on what management might say about yields looking forward into the summer in the conference call.

PM11:57am

To understand Ryanair you need to understand O'Leary

11:56 am
PM11:57am

Friend of mine did his biography

PM11:57am

Alan Ruddock -- (die too young)

PM11:57am

If you can get a copy it's a terrific read

11:57 am
PM11:57am

https://www.thegua...biography.features

undefined
PM11:58am

(Is Trump still in bed?)

11:57 am
PM11:58am

(No Tweets as yet)

BE11:58am

(He didn't get riled enough to tweet until about midday EST yesterday.)

BE11:58am

(The lie-in didn't seem to do his logical processing much good though.)

11:59 am
BE11:59am

(As time went on I found myself hoping he'd lost his phone or .... uh .... something else............... might've ............. happened ............ to ...................... him.)

BE11:59am

@Lefevre, sorry, nothing interesting on housebuilders.

BE12:01pm

The weekend stuff with regards the housing bill felt a bit please-all. We need to see the actual proposals rather than vague stuff about opening the debate on green belts and retirement home provision and blah blah blah.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Shore is the go-to broker for housing, though. And not just because they're doomy. Here's Robin Hardy.

BE12:02pm

The leaks and briefings are in full flight which seems to confirm that the long-awaited and long-overdue housing white paper will finally be published tomorrow (Tuesday 7th). There are any number of suggested new initiatives but overall, as we had suspected by the lack of prior knowledge that the house builders seemed to possess, that the proposals are setting the housing market off in directions other than simply throwing money at creating demand for houses built by the larger house builders.

BE12:02pm

· The focus looks to be on building more homes for rent, although it is not clear whether this is for private sector, public sector or both. The focus looks to be on providing more secure tenure with minimum terms of occupation – we have long felt that many potential house buyers would be happy to rent if a 3, 5, 7or even 10 year tenancy was on offer. This could, therefore, drain some demand from new build.

· Also the house builders’ wish that the Green Belt is opened up for development (this would provide high demand and premium priced housing) looks to have been rejected.

· There is talk of finding ways to ‘persuade’ pensioners who under-occupy large family houses to downsize and this may also include stimulus for retirement housing.

· Modular or factory-built housing may be made a requirement on certain new sites

· There could be punitive action taken against what the government sees as excessive holding of undeveloped land. This could be revoking of planning consents or some form of tax on land that has planning but is not under development. This would be a negative for the large builders with the longest landbanks.

· The annual housing target could be raised as high as 300,000 which is essentially double the current output. This would put an acute squeeze on industry capacity.

· A focus of development on inner city and rail-hub locations. Few house builders operate in these areas, preferring greenfield locations.

· Support for SME house builders. This sector has been struggling to access finances and the skew in the planning to large sites has been a disadvantage to smaller builders.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Overall, it looks to be policy moving away from the established new build model and this does create pressures on demand and cost for the quoted house builders and could also begin to undermine their current pricing - not like for like price falls but becoming harder to keep raising prices and revenues by driving further and further upmarket. New homes are becoming less affordable on this basis and policy may put pressure on this trend. We have referred many times to the sector enjoying many super-normal trading and market positions and if policy is skewed as suggested in the early leaks, then there is a material risk that things like high margins, high free cash, low land prices, the drive upmarket and the low levels of affordable housing could combine to make growth harder and could re-base profitability. So, we continue to see that upside in the sector has to be more limited and that the low ratings present today are discounting troubles ahead rather than describing a materially under-valued sector.
